1115604096700932102.text:
Polkadot Relay guarantees

- One parachain will not be reverted alone
- Messages always correspond to a valid state-transition on sending parachain
But what about parachains that upgrade themselves? Maybe a valid state transition on the upgraded chain breaks previous assumptions?pic.twitter.com/p2vv3FUPCu

1115602543336235008.text:
SPREE (aka Trust wormholes)
"smart protocol" - /u/tawaran

SPREE: Shared Protected Runtime Execution Environments
- Executes alongside parachain
- Protected: storage cannot be altered by parachain logic; messages cannot be faked from them by parachainspic.twitter.com/ihmAVyDScn

1115602304411897857.text:
SPREE (aka Trust wormholes)
"smart protocol" - /u/tawaran
SPREE: Shared Protected Runtime Execution Environments
- Parachains can opt-in to special runtime logic fragments (like smart contracts)
- Own storage & ICMP endpoint 
- All instances across parachains have identical logicpic.twitter.com/FtiriDleGh

1115598611700518912.text:
SPREE

SPREE: Shared Protected Runtime Execution Environments 

- Solves general problem of trust between parachains
- Even when parachains can upgrade themselvespic.twitter.com/fbU5hpg321

1115597967321251840.text:
What's up?

In progress:

- Offline Phragmen
- Interchain messaging 
- Final governance 
- BABE block productionpic.twitter.com/RqZblZNWuf

1115597096294408192.text:
Why not stake?

- Tokens locked for ~12 weeks
- Punishment in case of validator found to be misbehaving 
- Designed to be minimal when "accidental" and non-dangerous for the network
- Heavy when safety/liveness of the network is jeopardizedpic.twitter.com/rSlbsGlT7Z

1115594886504300544.text:
Polkadot parachain deployment:

- Auction every 6 months
- Candle auction (open with random end time)
- Retroactive ending 
- 6-month quantized slots 
- 2 years at a time
- Several lots for each slotpic.twitter.com/CplFv5mTCF

1103689471399215106.text: “Rather than counting slot numbers based on division of some global clock, BABE uses a relative time method, where each party has a local clock. This clock does not need to be synchronized with the rest of the network.” - @rphmeier at #EthCC2019

1103662103259463682.text: "Being a finality gadget, it relies on a block production system to produce blocks. We show liveness for GRANDPA when combined with all block production systems that build upon the best finalized block" - @rphmeier at #EthCCpic.twitter.com/mOpbQI07a2

1103658289060040704.text: "We're the first to implement this type of consensus, where votes are cast on chains and not blocks." - @rphmeier at #EthCC

1103658099959889920.text: "Accountable safety is the property that safety violations can be traced to specific misbehavior. GRANDPA does this with a synchronous procedure to track down equivocations or unjustified votes." - @rphmeier at #EthCC2019

1102905307079077898.text: “To sum it all up, Cumulus gives you consensus and synchronization, a collator node, and tools for writing runtimes that send and receive messages from other parachains.” - @rphmeier at #EthCCpic.twitter.com/XbDUq6al23

1102905306034651136.text: "Cumulus is a set of libraries meant to turn already written Substrate chains into a Polkadot parachains with minimal code changes” - @rphmeier at #EthCC

1102905304914845696.text: "Cumulus is an instantiation of pluggable consensus. It knows how to run another blockchain node internally and follow the Polkadot relay chain." - @rphmeier at #EthCC

1102905302914162688.text: “This is why we built Parity #Substrate, a toolkit for building blockchains more easily. Substrate has a bunch of pre-built modules that allow you to build a blockchain and focus on your chain’s specific logic.” - @rphmeier on @ParityTech at #EthCCpic.twitter.com/dHGqHelvIV

1102905301018267649.text: “Parachains are simple abstractions, but are hard to implement. Here is a “short list” of things you need to do!” - @rphmeier at #EthCCpic.twitter.com/2n5W93edmU

1102905299902566405.text: “The other half of building a parachain is writing the collator node. This is harder than writing the validation function. It has to have the logic for handling the incoming messages to the parachain and connecting parachain nodes.” - @rphmeier at #EthCC

1102905297671208960.text: “The biggest part of parachains are the validation function. It’s a piece of WebAssembly code that looks like this:" - @rphmeier at #EthCCpic.twitter.com/NirThZvs43

1102905295142113281.text: “Cumulus is a library for building #Substrate modules and parachains.” - @rphmeier at #EthCCpic.twitter.com/QTUkUFu84x

1067132827894988804.text: Polkadot is optimized so that applications can add modules that all other chains may find useful. A decentralized exchange parachain could add a DEX module to each chain that might need it to pool order books.pic.twitter.com/C5ZSiGVP1e

1067132825219018753.text: Polkadot is "infrastructure for infrastructure." The first chains to appear on Polkadot will probably not be useful by themselves, but will provide infrastructure (e.g. oracles parachain or a file storage parachain). But what about applications?pic.twitter.com/1Kngg1l350

1067132821641338880.text:
Why not bridge all chains together? If chains have different levels of security they can't reliably trust each other. Weak chain can be attacked or reverted while the others continue without realizing. 

Polkadot brings all chains under a single consensus and security system.pic.twitter.com/DrO68iteAm

1067132819997147136.text: "Every blockchain is trying to be a smart contract platform, a currency, have its own consensus, etc. This defeats the purpose of blockchains. We don't want people to be locked into a specific platform. We want them to be able to talk to each other." - @rphmeierpic.twitter.com/Ez62iacXot

Polkadot's roadmap. We are a few days off of PoC-3, which includes Polkadot's novel consensus algorithm.

1061598377568333825.text:
Polkadot v1 (2019): One relay chain supporting up to 100 parachains. 

Polkadot v2 (2020): Multiple relay chains, each hosting ~100 parachains. 

Potential Polkadot parachains at genesis: 
- Wasm based smart contracts platform
- Payments chain
- Ethereum bridge
- ZK-Snarks chainpic.twitter.com/22I6SWyPl3

1061598371029438465.text:
What do I get with Substrate? 
- Pluggable consensus (change consensus on the fly)
- Upgrade chain (without hard fork)
- A light client
- JavaScript implementation
- Runtime module library
- Interchain connectivity w/ Polkadot
- All this & more, for free!pic.twitter.com/ov6fubKepU

1061598365899743233.text:
Substrate is a technology stack that makes it extremely easy to build DAppchains and blockchains. 

Polkadot is a protocol that enables blockchains to communicate (this is optional for Substrate-based chains). 

Create a custom Substrate chain today: http://substrate.readme.io/docs/creating-a-custom-substrate-chain …pic.twitter.com/qW4R3v2Wac

1061598362363928577.text: Polkadot is the biggest bet in the ecosystem against chain maximalism. Even if there were one perfect chain, it won't stay perfect for very long. Chain maximalism creates barriers to entry and slows innovation.pic.twitter.com/vmhsy5XIYW

1012743891387322369.text:
PBFT finality happens every ~30 seconds while Aurand blocks are proposed every ~4-5 seconds, potentially faster.

4/6

1012743888241651714.text:
With Aurand one randomly chosen validator may propose a block, which *may be reverted* (faster). They are punished (slashed) for proposing invalid blocks or for going offline.

With PBFT > 2/3 of staked validators must sign-off to *guarantee finality* (slower).

3/6

1012743886211608576.text:
The PBFT derivative provides absolute finality. Aurand, a derivative of Aura, provides fast, simple, and intermediate finality.

Every so many blocks there is a PBFT check-point that guarantees finality, while the Aurand sets up the intermediary states of finality. 

2/6

1012743882436763648.text:
Polkadot uses a hybrid PBFT / Aurand consensus mechanism that has two degrees of finality. 

This consensus mechanism allows for relatively low latency state transitions while mitigating certain attacks to the network.

1/6pic.twitter.com/kgvfu0RbO4

1006997218069540865.text:
Unless 100% of DOT holders vote, a super majority (>50%) is required to pass referenda. If there is 100% voter turnout a simple 50% majority carries. 

Basically, the lower the turnout, the greater percentage of yes votes there needs to be (the inverse is also true).

4/5

1006997216807055360.text:
If you think a proposal is important you can add more bonds to it, i.e sponsor it. Every set time period the most sponsored proposal is voted on.

3/5

1006997214793740288.text:
The Council is an on-chain entity comprised of a group of accounts. It represents passive stakeholders and sets the defaults if no one shows up to vote on Referenda.

Referenda are proposals anyone can make to Polkadot’s governance system by locking up DOTs. 

2/5

1006997212235288577.text:
Polkadot uses a 1st of its kind on-chain governance system that is in itself adaptive and upgradeable. Founded around the idea of stakeholder voting, all changes to the protocol must be agreed upon by >50% of staked DOTs.

Two critical pieces are the Council and Referenda...

1/5pic.twitter.com/I5IHviCIq6

Here's how Polkadot tackles the most challenging problems facing the blockchain ecosystem. -https://medium.com/@polkadotnetwork/how-polkadot-tackles-the-biggest-problems-facing-blockchain-innovators-1affc1309b0f …

1004396696946860035.text:
To check if your account indicated a desire to stake, navigate to >Storage https://poc-1.polkadot.io/#/storage  and select “staking” and “intentions()”.

Click “+”, and search for your address. If you find it, everything worked! You are now in the queue to stake on Polkadot’s POC-1!

/Endpic.twitter.com/HtfgrVDOJA

1004396694400880640.text:
Now that you have your test DOTs, you’re ready to stake. 

Head back to the UI under >Extrinsics https://poc-1.polkadot.io/#/extrinsics  and select the account storing your test DOTs. Select “Staking” and “stake()” using the two dropdown menus.

Click “Submit Extrinsic”.

3/4pic.twitter.com/8SSsrI9mSo

1004396691867471872.text:
Navigate to https://poc-1.polkadot.io/#/accounts  and select “Create account”. Choose a password and click “Save”.

Next, copy your address from the UI and paste it to our Riot channel https://riot.im/app/#/room/#polkadot-watercooler:matrix.org …. 

A Polkadot team member will then send you test DOTs.

2/4pic.twitter.com/1PS8chZPmj

1004396690227556352.text:
Practice running a PoS validator node with Polkadot's POC-1 testnet! 

Learn how in the following Tweets…

Background: 22 accounts have indicated an intention to stake. New validators are chosen every 24 hours. Just remember to keep your node running 24/7!

1/4
